author: STEPHANIE SCHULTE
title: RIVERSIDE: Margaret Cho finds laughter through the pain
text:
BY STEPHANIE SCHULTE / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 21, 2015 11:07 a.m. RIVERSIDE: Margaret Cho finds laughter through the pain Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 3 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Comedian Margaret Cho will perform at the Fox Performing Arts Center in Riverside on Friday, Oct. 23. , MARY TAYLOR Related article » IF YOU GO When : 7 p.m. Friday, Oct. 23
Where : Fox Performing Arts Center, 3801 Mission Inn Ave., Riverside.
Admission : $35-$55, plus fees.
Information : 951-779-9800, riversidelive.com .
With a history of bullying and abuse, Margaret Cho found comfort in an unlikely place: on stage before crowds of people.
Under the lights and behind a microphone was where she felt at ease and empowered.
“I felt safe on stage because I had witnesses,” she said during a recent phone interview. “Having witnesses and being on stage healed me.”
Telling jokes in front of audiences since she was a teen, the 46-year-old Korean American comic and actress makes it a point to weave humor even into the darkest corners of her past.
The bold comedian said she will take on tough topics with a funny spin at the Fox Performing Arts Center on Friday, Oct. 23 as part of the psyCHO Tour.
Cho said mixing humor with touchy subjects such as gun violence, rape, racism and bullying is a complicated process. She said she is well aware these topics can make some audience members uncomfortable, so she is quick to find funny ways to let them off the hook.
“You have to combine sensibilities into it,” she said. “I’m safe and compassionate and trying to empower people with comedy.”
Cho’s calling came early, who said she was bullied as a child for looking different and found refuge among jokes.
When she started performing at small clubs in San Francisco as a teen, she didn’t hold back – one of the first jokes she remembers telling that had the audience laughing was about her heritage and stereotypes.
“At that time, in the ‘80s, comics were making fun of Asian drivers, that was the big joke,” she said, laughing. “So when I got onstage at 15, I said ‘My name is Margaret Cho and I drive very well.’”
In 1994, ABC debuted the sitcom “All-American Girl,” starring Cho and a predominantly Asian American cast; a television moment that many people viewed as a cultural milestone. The show, which was based on her stand-up routines, was panned by critics and canceled after one season. Cho has been public about her ensuing depression and drug addiction following the sitcom’s demise.
Over the years Cho went on to appear on numerous television shows, including a recent stint as a guest host on E!’s “Fashion Police,” where she added her comedic input on red carpet fashion at the MTV Video Music Awards. She has also been featured in movies and several stand-up specials.
A taping from her current tour debuted on Showtime last month.
She said although her set changes up from city to city, she won’t shy away from discussing “deep truths” at each stop.
“Performing is a living breathing art form,” she said. “Every city is different and every club is different.”
When it comes to being heckled, she said she becomes “Cho-bi-Wan Kenobi.”
“You have to be like a Jedi with hecklers,” she said.
After her shows she said audience members come up to her and thank her for being blunt and many times share personal stories of similar experiences, which she said is really beautiful and sad.
“Performing is like my religion, it is my spiritual practice,” Cho said. “If you mix highbrow with lowbrow comedy then you get the breadth of a genius.”
